metadata.title: Exploring the impact of S-doped Fe-N-C materials on the ORR mechanism within a constant potential solvation model

Fig. 1 The atomic structures of FeN4S-N and optimized reaction models during ORR catalyzed by pyridinic FeN4S2 at −2.0 e. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Ionic countercharge density isosurfaces of 1 × 10−7 e/Å −3 for *OOH adsorbed on pyrrolic FeN4S2 corresponding to (a) −1.92 V/SHE and (b) 1.31 V/SHE, adjusted by adding and removing two, respectively. The cyan and yellow areas indicated positively and negatively charged ions, respectively. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Formation energy (eV) and binding energy (eV) of FeN4S-N. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Free energy diagram for the oxygen reduction process on FeN4S-N at 0 V and 1.23 V under vacuum environment. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Calculated energies of the FeN4S-N and corresponding three reaction intermediates as a function of the applied electrode potential. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Contour plot of Bader charge and potential dependent adsorption energy of O2 on FeN4S-N. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Free energy diagrams of ORR for FeN4S-N under constant potential implicit solvent model. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Structures of the initial state (IS), transition state (TS), and final state (FS) of ORR elemental steps on FeN4S2 (−2.0 e); the corresponding energy barriers and reaction energy are also marked: (a) *O2 + H + → *OOH; (b) *OOH + H + → *O + H2O; (c) *O + H + → *OH; (d) *OH + H + → *H2O. Fig 8 Research Paper Exploring the impact of S-doped Fe-N-C materials on the ORR mechanism within a constant potential solvation model Penghui Ren Conceptualization Writing – original draft a ⁎ Zhongbao Feng Software c Ying Zhao Visualization a Chunyang Liu Data curation a Huixia Li Data curation a Ruopeng Li Writing – review & editing b ⁎ Xuebo Chen Conceptualization Data curation a ⁎ a Shandong Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Green Manufacturing at Yantai, Yantai 264000, China Shandong Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Green Manufacturing at Yantai Yantai 264000 China aShandong Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Green Manufacturing at Yantai, Yantai 264000, China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Harbin Institute of Technology Harbin 150001 China bSchool of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, China c Key Laboratory for Ecological Metallurgy of Multimetallic Mineral (Ministry of Education), Northeastern University, Shenyang 110819, China Key Laboratory for Ecological Metallurgy of Multimetallic Mineral (Ministry of Education) Northeastern University Shenyang 110819 China cKey Laboratory for Ecological Metallurgy of Multimetallic Mineral (Ministry of Education), Northeastern University, Shenyang 110819, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The widespread application of S doping in Fe-N-C materials aims to enhance the catalytic activity for oxygen reduction reactions (ORR). However, the current doping strategies are primarily centered on the first coordination layer encompassing Fe atoms. Consequently, this study employs first-principles calculations to compute the formation and binding energies of FeN4 doped with S atom. It further delves into the influence of diverse doping sites on catalyst stability and meticulously analyzes the configurations and corresponding ORR activities of four catalysts, namely FeN4S-N (Number=0∼3), utilizing a constant-potential implicit solvent model to simulate authentic electrocatalytic environments. The findings reveal that under vacuum conditions, FeN4S1 exhibits the utmost ORR activity, boasting a potential of 0.53 V. Conversely, within the constant-potential implicit solvation model, FeN4S2 emerges as the catalyst with the highest ORR activity, achieving a potential of 0.39 V. Therefore, calculations leveraging the constant-potential solvation model offer more realistic insights into catalyst design, thereby guiding the development of superior catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Implicit solvent model Single atom catalysts ORR mechanisms Constant-potential Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Over the past few years, the extravagant consumption of traditional energy has led to global energy depletion and environmental pollution [1–3]. To address the above issues, researchers have conducted research on various clean energy technologies, such as proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) [4–6], due to its high energy efficiency, high energy density, and negligible exhaust emissions, it has been regarded as an important research direction. Although PEMFC have many advantages, its oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) kinetic process is relatively slow, which has become an important research barrier in the development of PEMFC [7]. At present stage, the cathode catalyst for proton exchange membrane batteries is composed of Pt/C on the market. However, Pt has disadvantages such as high price, scarcity, and poor durability, which makes it impossible for PEMFC to be widely used in automobiles [8–10]. Therefore, as a cheaper and less polluting non precious metal catalyst, it has become a favored object for researchers. During the research period of proton exchange membranes, transition metal oxides and multiple heteroatoms-doped carbon materials became the main research objects of cathode catalysts [11–13]. The co-doping of transition metal and non-metallic atoms has the characteristics of high activity and low cost in graphene catalysts. Ma et al. [14] compared the electronic properties, adsorption energy, structural stability and catalytic activity of ruthenium nitrogen co-doped graphene catalysts with single atom ruthenium doped graphene catalysts. They found that the structure of ruthenium is stable and the ORR crossing point is lower. Bhatt et al. [15] applied density functional theory to calculate the 2-electron transport pathway and 4-electron transport pathway in the ORR process of M-N2-G (M=Ti, Cu, Mo, Nb and Ru) catalyst, and compared their electrocatalytic performance. The calculation results indicate that the four electron transfer paths are more likely to occur on the surface of M-N2-G (M=Ti, Mo, Nb and Ru), and the energy required to generate water molecules is lower. Xiao et al. [16] used first principles calculations to investigate the oxygen reduction and evolution reactions of TMN4 (TM=Fe, Co and Ni) encapsulated graphene and fluorographene in order to develop metal air batteries with better performance. They found that TMN4 improved the ORR/OER activity of graphene, especially with H/F modified catalysts. During the ORR process, ηORR of G/FeN4, G/FeN4 and GF/FeN4 are 0.98 V, 0.46 V and 0.38 V, respectively, and the CoN4 has better OER activity, ηORR of G/CoN4, G/CoN4 and GF/CoN4 are −0.73 V, −0.50 V and −0.53 V, respectively. Based on the above results, it can be seen that FeN4 has broader development prospects as metal air batteries catalysts. Recent studies have shown that sulfur atom doping can reduce the adsorption strength of Fe centers to oxygen-containing intermediates, thereby improving the intrinsic activity of Fe-N-C catalysts. Xu and his team [17] successfully prepared a Fe-N-S-C catalyst with high intrinsic activity by substituting nitrogen atoms in FeN4 with sulfur atoms. Experimental results have demonstrated that the Fe-N-S-C catalyst exhibits high porosity and abundant active sites, achieving a half-wave potential of 0.9 V and excellent stability under 0.1 M KOH conditions. Furthermore, its ORR performance in all-solid-state zinc-air batteries has been further verified, displaying high power densities of 109 and 68 mW cm−2, respectively, as well as good discharge stability. However, the optimal doping site of sulfur atoms in FeN4 remains to be studied. Therefore, this paper adopts the first-principles method to calculate the formation energy, binding energy, density of states, charge, adsorption energy, and redox process of Fe-N-S-C catalysts containing different sulfur sites (see Fig. 1a∼1d ). Among them, the most important aspect is the changes in the interaction between different oxygen-containing intermediates and the catalyst. Therefore, to simulate the electrochemical catalytic reaction process under realistic conditions, solvation effects and constant potential have been added to the model to obtain the changes in the adsorption configurations of oxygen-containing intermediates on the catalyst surface. 2 Computational method This paper applies the density-functional theory (DFT) [18–20] method to calculate all materials in the article using Vienna ab-initio simulation package (VASP) [21,22], and the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [23–26] exchange-correlation energy with Hubbard correction (+U) is employed. The adopted U values for Fe is 4.30 eV [27]. function within the generalized gradient approximation was applied by the exchange-correlation energy. The convergence criteria for energy and force during the optimization process were 0.01 eV/Å and 10−5 eV, respectively. The cutoff energy and K-point were set to 500 eV and 3 × 3 × 1, respectively [28]. The vacuum layer thickness of the model was 15 Å in the z-direction for avoiding interaction between planes. The zero damping DFT-D3 method of Grimme was used to consider the van der Waals interaction forces [29]. The climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method was used to calculate the reaction transition state and potential energy barrier of oxygen-containing intermediates on the catalyst surface [30]. The model solvent environment was constructed using the VASPsol code [31], with a relative permittivity of 80 simulating the aqueous electrolyte, an effective surface tension parameter of 0, and no consideration of cavitation energy. The linearized Poissobn-Boltzmann model with a Debye length of 3 Å mimics the compensating charge. To describe the reaction mechanism of intermediates at different electrode potentials, the excess charge of the unit cell was varied from −2.0 e to +2.0 e in increments of 0.5 e in this study [32]. Fig. 2 showed an example of the coupling between application potential, adsorption configuration, and corresponding ion distribution. The data obtained from VASP calculations were post-processed using the VASPKIT code [33]. In this study, graphene was used as the original model, with two C atoms removed to fix the Fe atom. Four surrounding C atoms were then replaced with four N atoms, and S atom was substituted for C atoms in the vicinity of the Fe atom, starting from the nearest and proceeding outward, to construct the FeN4S-N (Number=0∼3) catalyst. The formation energy, binding energy and adsorption energy are obtained by Eqs. (1)∼(5) [34–37]. (1) E f = E c a t a l y s t + x μ C − ( E G + y μ N + E M + z E S ) (2) E b = E c a t a l y s t − E G − E M (3) E a d s ( * O O H ) = E ( * O O H ) − E ( s l a b ) − 2 E ( H 2 O ) + 3 2 E ( H 2 ) (4) E a d s ( * O ) = E ( * O ) − E ( s l a b ) − E ( H 2 O ) + E ( H 2 ) (5) E a d s ( * O H ) = E ( * O H ) − E ( s l a b ) − E ( H 2 O ) + 1 2 E ( H 2 ) Where, Ecatalyst, EG and EM are catalyst energy in a solvent-free environment, graphene sheet and single metal atom, respectively. µC is the chemical potential of the energy of a single carbon atom on intact graphene, and x is the number of carbon atoms replaced. µN is half the energy of nitrogen molecules, y represents the number of nitrogen atoms on the catalyst. ES is the energy of single sulfur atom, and z represents the number of S atom doped in the catalytic sheet. The potential- dependent energy of the model (E) is defined in Eq. (6). [31] (6) E = E D F T − Δ n ( V s o l + Φ q / e ) Here, EDFT is the DFT-calculated energy, Vsol is the electrostatic potential of the bulk electrolyte, and -Φq is the work function of the charged system. The referenced to the standard hydrogen electrode (SHE) scale is formulated in Eq. (7). (7) U q ( V / S H E ) = − 4.6 V − Φ / e The energy change of each reaction in the ORR process can be obtained from Eq. (8) [38,39]. (8) Δ G = Δ E D F T + Δ Z P E − T Δ S − n e U + Δ G p H Here, the ΔEDFT is the calculated DFT reaction energy, ΔZPE is the change in zero-point energy (ZPE) calculated from the vibrational frequencies and ΔS is the change in the entropy referring to thermodynamics databases. The reference potential during the reaction process is adjusted to standard hydrogen electrode (SHE), n and U are the number of transferred electrons and electrode potential, respectively. ΔGpH=kBT × ln10 × pH, here, kB is the Boltzmann constant, and in this work, we assume that the ORR reaction environment is an acidic system, where pH is equal to 0. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Electronic characters and structure stability Four different configurations of catalysts (FeN4S0∼FeN4S3) were constructed in this study, and their formation energies were calculated using Eq. (1), as shown in Table S1 and Fig. 3 . According to Table S1 and Fig. 3, the catalyst materials were easier to synthesize without doping with S atom, with the formation energy of FeN4S0 being −5.80 eV. However, after doping S atom into FeN4S0, the formation energy of FeN4S2 was the highest, with a value of −2.99 eV. In addition, in order to analyze the stability of four catalyst materials, Eq. (2) was used to calculate the binding energy of the catalyst, and they were shown in Fig. 3. The binding energy of FeN4S0∼FeN4S3 were ordered by −1.24 eV (FeN4S0) > −1.01 eV (FeN4S2) > −0.73 eV (FeN4S3) > −0.60 eV (FeN4S1). Based on the above results, it could be concluded that FeN4S0 exhibits the best stability, while FeN4S2 exhibits the highest stability after doping with S atom. In the absence of a solvent environment and under the influence of electrode potential, we conducted a thorough analysis of the density of states (DOS) and Bader charges of four catalyst materials using VASP software. The DOS diagram of FeN4S0 exhibits a large energy gap of 0.38 eV (see Fig. S1). With the introduction of S atoms, the energy gaps of FeN4S1 and FeN4S2 narrow, and as the distance between Fe and S further increases, the energy gap of FeN4S2 correspondingly widens, which is consistent with the trend of charge variation. Specifically, we explored the changes in charge transfer between different atoms after doping with S atom, as shown in Fig. S2. When no S atom was doped, Fe in FeN4S0 acquires 1.04 e of electrons. However, due to the strong electronegativity of S atom, when S atom was doped into FeN4S0 to form FeN4S1 and FeN4S2, they acquired 0.96 e of electrons, respectively. As the distance between Fe and S increases, the number of electrons on Fe gradually increased, as illustrated in Fig. S2. This electron transfer results in an increase in the valence state of Fe in FeN4S1 and FeN4S2, which in turn reduced the adsorption capacity for oxygen-containing intermediates [40]. To gain a deeper understanding of the adsorption changes of oxygen-containing intermediates on the surface of the catalyst, we calculated the adsorption energies of oxygen-containing intermediates (O2, OOH, OH, and O) on the surface of the catalyst. According to the calculation results, oxygen-containing intermediates were more likely to adsorb on the metal sites of the catalyst. All calculation models, adsorption energies, and changes in interatomic distances were presented in Fig. S3, Tables S2, and S3. As the first step of the ORR reaction, the adsorption energy and morphology of O2 on the catalyst surface played a crucial role in subsequent reactions. Based on Fig. S3 ((a), (e), (i), and (m)) and Table S3, the adsorption model structures of O2 on the catalyst surface tend to have a certain angle, ranging from 102° to 134° In the FeN4S0 model, the adsorption energy of O2 is −2.50 eV (refer to Table S2). After doping with S atom, the absorption energy of O2 decreased to −1.97 eV, −2.14 eV, and −2.32 eV, respectively. Based on the above results, it could be seen that the addition of S atom weakens the adsorption capacity of Fe atoms for O2, and as the distance between S atom and Fe atoms changes, the distance between the catalyst and O2 also varied, being 1.77 Å, 1.80 Å, 1.76 Å, and 1.83 Å, respectively. As observed in Fig. S3 ((a), (e), (i), and (m)), O2 moved towards the position of S atom, resulting in significant changed in the angles between O2 and FeN4S-N. Even in the FeN4S3 model, the angle between O2 and FeN4S3 changed to 102° In the four-electron reaction process of ORR, once O2 was adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst, it would subsequently form *OOH, *O, and *OH in sequence. As clearly seen in Table S2, these oxygen-containing intermediates exhibited excellent adsorption states on the catalyst surface, which was crucial for ensuring the smooth progress of the ORR reaction. Upon further examination of Table S3, we observed that the distances and angle variations between these oxygen-containing intermediates and the catalyst surface remain within a narrow range, indicating stable adsorption characteristics. The strength of the adsorption states during the adsorption process of *OOH, *O, and *OH could be quantitatively represented by their adsorption energies on the FeN4S-N surface, with specific values detailed in Table S2. The data in Table S2 revealed that FeN4S-N exhibited relatively strong adsorption capabilities towards OOH, O, and OH, with OH adsorption being particularly prominent. The adsorption energies of OH on the FeN4S-N surface were −3.85 eV, −3.25 eV, −4.40 eV, and −3.93 eV, respectively. However, it was noteworthy that excessively strong adsorption energy can sometimes poison the catalytic surface, thereby hindering the smooth progress of the ORR reaction. FeN4S1 exhibited the weakest adsorption energy for OH among the four catalysts, thus making it the best candidate for promoting the ORR process. 3.2 ORR catalytic activity Based on the aforementioned data, we delved into the adsorption states and ORR activities of various oxygen-containing intermediates on the FeN4S-N catalyst surface. The primary focus of this paper was the four-electron process in the ORR reaction catalyzed by FeN4S-N [41,42]: (9) O 2 * + H + + e − → OO H * (10) OO H * + H + + e − → O * + H 2 O (11) O * + H + + e − → O H * (12) O H * + H + + e − → + H 2 O + * According to the ET-OHP mechanism [43], the first hydrogen ion on the outer Helmholtz plane first combined with O2 molecules to form OOH+, and then adsorbed on the catalytic site to form OOH*. The hydroxyl group was removed to form OH*, and finally continued hydrogenation to reduce to H2O. As shown in Fig. 4 , for the FeN4S-N catalyst, the Gibbs free energy of the four-step elementary reaction in the ORR reaction decreases, indicated that the reaction can occur spontaneously in thermodynamics (when U is equal to 0.00 V). From Fig. 4, it could be observed that the rate-determining step of FeN4S-N was the third step (U = 1.23 V), and their ηORR are 1.01 V, 0.53 V, 0.66 V and 1.16 V, respectively. Therefore, in Fe, N, S doped graphene materials, FeN4S1 had the smallest ηORR and the best ORR activity. To simulate a more realistic computational environment, the constant potential and solvent effects were incorporated into the FeN4S-N model. Therefore, this paper delved into the reaction mechanism based on the constant-potential implicit model. The calculated energies of the FeN4S-N catalyst as a function of the applied electrode potential (referenced to the SHE scale) were shown in Fig. 5 . The model energies of slab, *OOH, *O, and *OH exhibited a similar trend with the applied potential, first increasing and then decreasing. Among slab, *O, and *OH, the applied potential at zero charge shifted toward the positive direction as the distance between Fe and S atom changes, and then shifted toward the negative direction, while the applied potential of *OOH shifted continuously towards the negative direction. The relationship between the adsorption energies of the three oxygen-containing intermediates and the applied potential was shown in Fig. S4. For FeN4S0 and FeN4S1, the adsorption energies of the three oxygen-containing intermediates increase as the applied potential shifts from the negative direction to the positive direction. For FeN4S2, the adsorption energies of the three oxygen-containing intermediates first increase and then decrease with the shift of the applied voltage, which was different from the previous three catalysts. The adsorption energy of the OOH model adsorbed on FeN4S3 first increases and then decreases with the shift of the applied voltage, while the adsorption energies of *O and *OH continuously increased with the shift of the applied voltage. These varying degrees of correlation would affect the rate-determining step (RDS) and onset potential at different applied potentials, which would be discussed in detail below. Based on the potential-dependent adsorption energies of oxygen-containing intermediates and the reaction mechanism, we obtained contour plots of Bader charges referenced to the RHE scale (as shown in Fig. 6 ). O2 adsorption was the first step of the ORR reaction, and Fig. 6 revealed that as the applied potential shifts, the charge of the Fe atom in FeN4S-N decreases continuously, leading to an increase in its valence state and consequently a weakening of O2 adsorption on FeN4S-N. Among them, FeN4S2 exhibited the strongest adsorption capacity for O2, with an adsorption energy of −1.45 eV. Fig. 7 depicted the reaction pathways of the ORR process for four different catalysts under various applied voltages. As can be seen from Fig. 7, for FeN4S2 at a charge of −2.0 e, the RDS occurs at the fourth step of the reaction, and its overpotential was the smallest among all models and potentials, being −0.39 V. To further investigate the reaction activation of hydrogenation steps, we first considered the protonation of the O2 molecule on the FeN4S2 surface, leading to the formation of *OOH with an activation energy of 0.13 eV (as shown in Fig. 8 a). According to Fig. 8b, the activation energy barrier for the subsequent hydrogenation of OOH was 0.07 eV, indicating that the direct hydrogenation of O2 was energetically more favorable. After hydrogenation and dehydration of *OOH, *O was formed. In the subsequent steps, *O undergoes two consecutive hydrogenations to form *OH, ultimately leading to the production of H2O. The activation energy barriers for these steps were 0.14 eV and 0.31 eV, respectively. Combined with previous discussions, it could be seen that FeN4S2 exhibited a strong adsorption energy for O2 molecules under a −2.0 e environment, and the activation of O2 into *OOH requires only a low amount of energy. This suggested that the O2 molecules did not poison the FeN4S2 surface, and its overpotential of −0.39 V further supported the potential of FeN4S2 as a promising ORR catalyst. 4 Conclusions In summary, we conducted a detailed investigation into the impact of S atom doping on the ORR activity of Fe-N-C materials, encompassing the optimization of doping sites, material stability, and the calculation of charge transfer and ORR activity for FeN4S0 to FeN4S3 under both vacuum and constant-potential implicit solvent models. The calculation results indicate that although S atom doping increases the synthesis difficulty of the catalyst, its high electronegativity enhances the valence state of Fe atoms, reduces the adsorption energy of intermediates, and thereby promotes the ORR reaction process. By comparing the results obtained under vacuum conditions and the constant-potential implicit solvent model, we found that FeN4S1 exhibits the highest ORR activity with a potential of 0.53 V in vacuum. However, within the constant-potential implicit solvation model, FeN4S2 demonstrates the highest ORR activity with a potential of 0.39 V. Therefore, calculations employing the constant-potential solvation model provide more realistic insights for catalyst design and can serve as a guide for developing superior catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The widespread application of S doping in Fe-N-C materials aims to enhance the catalytic activity for oxygen reduction reactions (ORR). However, the current doping strategies are primarily centered on the first coordination layer encompassing Fe atoms. Consequently, this study employs first-principles calculations to compute the formation and binding energies of FeN4 doped with S atom. It further delves into the influence of diverse doping sites on catalyst stability and meticulously analyzes the configurations and corresponding ORR activities of four catalysts, namely FeN4S-N (Number=0∼3), utilizing a constant-potential implicit solvent model to simulate authentic electrocatalytic environments. The findings reveal that under vacuum conditions, FeN4S1 exhibits the utmost ORR activity, boasting a potential of 0.53 V. Conversely, within the constant-potential implicit solvation model, FeN4S2 emerges as the catalyst with the highest ORR activity, achieving a potential of 0.39 V. Therefore, calculations leveraging the constant-potential solvation model offer more realistic insights into catalyst design, thereby guiding the development of superior catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Exploring the impact of S-doped Fe-N-C materials on the ORR mechanism within a constant potential solvation model
